questions.text: One health assistant, male/female, should be posted for every
questions.solution:
Explanation:

One health assistant, whether male or female, should be posted for every 30,000 population. This is based on the standard guidelines for healthcare workforce allocation and distribution.

Explanation of incorrect options

5000 population (Option A ruled out): This option would result in a much higher ratio of health assistants to population compared to the recommended standard. Such a low ratio may not be efficient or cost-effective in terms of healthcare resource allocation.

20000 population (Option B ruled out): While this ratio would be an improvement over Option A, it is still lower than the recommended standard of one health assistant for every 30,000 population. This could potentially lead to an inadequate distribution of healthcare personnel, resulting in underserved areas.

10000 population (Option D ruled out): Similar to Option B, this ratio would also be lower than the recommended standard. Allocating one health assistant for every 10,000 population may result in healthcare disparities and unequal access to healthcare services across different regions or communities.

questions.text: Urban social health activist (USHA) workers are proposed to work for the population of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is A. Urban Social Health Activist (USHA) workers are proposed to work for a population range of 1000-2500.

Explanation of incorrect options

2500-3500 (Option B): This range is slightly higher than the proposed range for USHA workers. While some flexibility might exist in practice, it's generally recommended for USHA workers to serve smaller populations to ensure effective coverage and personalized care.

4000-5000 (Option C): This range exceeds the proposed range for USHA workers. Assigning USHA workers to populations of this size might stretch their resources thin and compromise the quality of care they can provide.

5000-10000 (Option D): This range is significantly larger than the proposed range for USHA workers. It would be challenging for USHA workers to effectively address the healthcare needs of such large populations while maintaining personalized care and accessibility.

questions.text: All of the following are pillars of primary health care except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Health education is indeed a fundamental aspect of primary health care, and it is considered one of the pillars alongside equitable distribution, community participation, and intersectoral coordination.

Explanation of incorrect options

Equitable distribution (Option A): This is a key principle of primary health care, emphasizing the fair allocation of healthcare resources and services to ensure that everyone has access to essential healthcare regardless of socioeconomic status, geography, or other factors.

Community participation (Option B): In primary health care, community participation is vital for ensuring that healthcare services meet the needs and preferences of the local population. It involves engaging community members in decision-making processes, empowering them to take ownership of their health, and fostering partnerships between healthcare providers and the community.

Intersectoral coordination (Option D): Primary health care recognizes that improving health outcomes requires collaboration across multiple sectors beyond healthcare, such as education, housing, agriculture, and transportation. Intersectoral coordination involves integrating efforts and resources from various sectors to address the social determinants of health and promote holistic well-being.

questions.text: The Elements of primary health care include all the following except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A sound referral system is not one of the eight essential components of primary health care.

The eight components include:

  • Health education
  • Proper nutrition
  • Safe water and sanitation
  • Maternal and child health care
  • Immunization
  • Prevention and control of endemic diseases
  • Appropriate treatment of common illnesses
  • Provision of essential drugs

Referral systems help move patients from primary to secondary/tertiary care when needed.

Though referrals may occur in primary care, building a full referral system involves broader healthcare coordination, beyond just primary health care.

Explanation of incorrect options

Adequate supply of safe water and basic sanitation (Option A): Access to clean water and proper sanitation is essential for preventing waterborne diseases and promoting public health. It is a fundamental component of primary health care as it addresses the basic environmental determinants of health.

Providing essential drugs (Option B): Ensuring access to essential drugs is a crucial aspect of primary health care. It involves making essential medications available and affordable to all individuals, especially in resource-limited settings. This helps in managing common health conditions and preventing complications.

Health education (Option D): Health education plays a vital role in primary health care by empowering individuals and communities to make informed decisions about their health. It involves raising awareness about preventive measures, healthy lifestyles, and the importance of seeking timely medical care. Health education promotes health literacy and encourages active participation in maintaining well-being.

questions.text: PHC is designed as Type A if it conducts less than _____ specified number of deliveries
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Primary Health Centres (PHCs) are an integral part of the healthcare infrastructure, especially in rural areas, providing essential primary healthcare services to the population. The categorization of PHCs into Type A, B, or C depends on various factors, including the number of deliveries conducted.

A Type A PHC is one that handles fewer than 20 deliveries per month, while a Type B PHC conducts 20 or more deliveries in a month

Explanation of incorrect options

10 (Option A): Too low to serve as the threshold; IPHS specifies 20.

15 (Option B): Below 20, but not the defined cut-off.

30 (Option D): Often associated with additional staffing norms-but not the classification boundary. PHC Type B staff upgrades are considered when delivery load is 30 or more, but classification into Type A vs. B uses the 20-delivery threshold

Community Health Centres (CHCs) are the second tier of the healthcare infrastructure in India, catering to a larger population than Primary Health Centres (PHCs) and providing comprehensive healthcare services. The population coverage of a CHC is crucial in determining its capacity and resources to serve the community effectively.

Option A (40-60,000) and Option B (60-80,000) reflect coverage populations typical of Primary Health Centres (PHCs)

questions.text: Optimum unit of preventive, promotive and curative services in health care is known as
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In healthcare, the term "comprehensiveness" refers to the provision of a wide range of preventive, promotive, and curative services to address the diverse health needs of individuals and communities.

Comprehensiveness: Comprehensiveness encompasses the holistic provision of preventive, promotive, and curative services aimed at addressing the overall health needs of individuals and communities. It emphasizes the importance of offering a broad spectrum of interventions, including health education, immunization, screening, diagnosis, treatment, and follow-up care, to achieve optimal health outcomes.

Explanation of incorrect options

Appropriateness (Option A): Refers to the suitability of a specific intervention for a particular condition-not the breadth of services offered.

Availability (Option B): Addresses the presence or accessibility of services but does not ensure the range or integration of services.

Adequacy (Option C): Concerns sufficiency of resources or services but again does not imply integration across service types.

questions.text:
Which of the following are criteria used for selecting village health guides?
1. Permanent resident of the local community
2. Preferably women
3. Minimum formal education of 6th standard
4. Should spare 8 hours daily for community
5. Acceptable to all sections of community
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is option C: 1, 2, 3, 5 only.

  1. Permanent resident of the local community: This criterion ensures that the village health guide has a strong connection to the community they serve, which can enhance trust, rapport, and understanding of local health needs and practices.
  2. Preferably women: In many cultures, women are often the primary caregivers and have better access to women and children within the community. Having female village health guides can facilitate discussions on sensitive health issues and improve the acceptance of healthcare services.
  3. Minimum formal education of 6th standard: While formal education is not always a prerequisite for being an effective village health guide, a minimum level of education, such as completing the 6th standard, can ensure basic literacy and numeracy skills necessary for understanding health-related information, record-keeping, and communication.
  4. Should spare 8 hours daily for the community: Requiring village health guides to spare 8 hours daily may be impractical and may not be feasible for individuals who have other responsibilities such as employment or caregiving duties. Moreover, it may deter qualified individuals from volunteering as health guides.
  5. Acceptable to all sections of the community: It is essential for village health guides to be accepted by all sections of the community to ensure their effectiveness and inclusivity in delivering healthcare services. This criterion emphasizes the importance of cultural sensitivity, interpersonal skills, and community acceptance.

Statement 4 (spare 8 hours daily): VHGs were expected to work approximately 2-3 hours per day post-training, not a full 8-hour commitment

questions.text: ORS given to children suffering from diarrhoea is based on which characteristics of essential care
questions.solution:
Explanation:

ORS (Oral Rehydration Solution) is a simple and effective treatment for children suffering from diarrhoea. It is based on the principle of appropriate technology, which means using simple, locally available resources to address a specific health problem. ORS is composed of a precise mixture of salts and sugars that help to replace lost fluids and electrolytes due to diarrhea, preventing dehydration and improving outcomes.

Explanation of incorrect options

Community participation (Option A): While community participation may play a role in the distribution and administration of ORS, it is not the primary characteristic upon which ORS is based. ORS is primarily a medical intervention aimed at treating dehydration caused by diarrhea.

Equitable distribution (Option B): Equitable distribution is an important principle in healthcare delivery, ensuring that essential services reach all individuals, regardless of their socio-economic status. While equitable distribution is important for ensuring access to ORS, it is not the characteristic upon which ORS itself is based.

Intersectoral coordination (Option C): Intersectoral coordination involves collaboration between different sectors of government and society to address complex health issues. While coordination between health and other sectors may be important for the overall success of diarrhoea management programs, it is not a defining characteristic of ORS itself.

questions.text: Population catered by Community health block
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Community Health Blocks, also known as Community Health Centres (CHCs) in some contexts, are designed to provide comprehensive primary healthcare services to a defined population. These facilities serve as referral centres for Primary Health Centres (PHCs) and typically cover a larger population area than PHCs. The population catered by a Community Health Block is generally around 100,000 people.

Explanation of incorrect options

5000 (Option A): This population size is more typical for the catchment area of a Sub-Centre, which is the most peripheral healthcare unit in India's healthcare system. Sub-Centres cater to around 3,000 to 5,000 people in rural areas.

30,000 (Option B): While this population size could be a catchment area for some larger health facilities, such as larger Primary Health Centres (PHCs) or Rural Hospitals, it is not typically the population catered by a Community Health Block.

10,000 (Option C): This population size is smaller and would be more appropriate for the catchment area of a Primary Health Centre (PHC). PHCs usually cover a population of around 20,000 to 30,000 people in rural areas.

questions.text: Which of the following should be present at PHC?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Primary Health Centres (PHCs) are the cornerstone of India's rural healthcare system and are intended to provide comprehensive primary healthcare services to the community they serve. While they are equipped with basic medical facilities, they may not typically have all the services mentioned in the options. The provision of safe abortion practices is an essential component of reproductive healthcare services that PHCs may offer

Explanation of incorrect options

Blood transfusion facility (Option A): While some PHCs may have the capability to provide basic blood transfusion services, this is not a universal feature. PHCs often lack the infrastructure and resources for maintaining blood banks and handling blood transfusions safely. Blood transfusion facilities are typically available at higher-level health facilities like Community Health Centers (CHCs) or district hospitals.

Caesarean section (Option B): PHCs are usually not equipped to perform major surgical procedures like Caesarean sections. These are typically carried out in hospitals with surgical facilities. PHCs focus more on providing maternal and child health services, including antenatal care, normal deliveries, and postnatal care. Complicated cases requiring Caesarean sections are referred to higher-level facilities.

All diagnostic services (Option D): While PHCs may offer basic diagnostic services like laboratory tests, X-rays, and ultrasound examinations, they may not have the capacity to provide all diagnostic services. Advanced diagnostic procedures and imaging studies are usually performed at higher-level healthcare facilities, such as district hospitals or specialized diagnostic centres.

ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist) is a key component of India's National Health Mission (NHM), tasked with delivering various healthcare services at the community level, especially in rural areas. questions.text: Use of Shakir's tape for MAC is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Shakir's tape, also known as Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC) tape, is a simple and cost-effective tool used to measure mid-upper arm circumference, particularly in children, to assess their nutritional status. This method is considered appropriate technology because it is:

  • Simple: The use of Shakir's tape is straightforward and does not require advanced training or technical skills. Health workers can easily measure MUAC with minimal training.
  • Cost-effective: MUAC tapes are inexpensive to produce and distribute, making them accessible even in resource-limited settings.
  • Reliable: Research has shown that MUAC measurement is a reliable indicator of nutritional status, particularly for detecting severe acute malnutrition.
  • Portable: MUAC tapes are lightweight and easy to transport, making them suitable for use in various settings, including community health centres, schools, and outreach programs.

Explanation of incorrect options

Equitable distribution (Option A): While the use of Shakir's tape can contribute to equitable health care delivery by providing a simple and effective tool for assessing malnutrition, its primary purpose is not related to distribution but rather to measurement.

Community participation (Option C): Although community health workers may be involved in using MUAC tapes to measure mid-upper arm circumference, the technology itself is not inherently linked to community participation. However, community members may participate in activities related to malnutrition screening and treatment, which can involve MUAC measurements.

Intersectoral coordination (Option D): Shakir's tape is primarily a tool for nutritional assessment and does not directly involve coordination between different sectors or departments. While addressing malnutrition may require collaboration between health, education, and social welfare sectors, the use of MUAC tapes specifically does not necessitate intersectoral coordination.

questions.text: The Most peripheral level of health care according to RCH
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Sub-Centre is the most peripheral level of health care according to the RCH program.

Explanation of incorrect options

Anganwadi (Option A): Anganwadi centers are part of the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) program in India. While they play a crucial role in providing supplementary nutrition, preschool education, and primary health care services to children under 6 years of age and pregnant and lactating mothers, they are not the most peripheral level of health care in the RCH program. They are community-based centers providing essential services but are not primarily health care facilities.

Sub-Centre (SC) (Option A): The Sub-Centre is the most peripheral level of health care according to the RCH program. Sub-centres are the first contact point between the primary health care system and the community. They are usually staffed by a trained health worker, typically an Auxiliary Nurse Midwife (ANM), and are responsible for providing essential primary health care services, including maternal and child health care, immunization, family planning, and health education, to a defined population in a specific geographic area.

District Hospital (Option C): District hospitals are secondary-level health care facilities that serve as referral centers for primary health care institutions like Sub-Centres and Primary Health Centers (PHCs). They provide more specialized services compared to Sub-Centres, such as inpatient care, surgery, diagnostics, and specialized medical treatment. They are not the most peripheral level of health care but rather serve as a higher level of care within the health care system.

Block/Taluk Hospital (Option D): Similar to district hospitals, Block/Taluk Hospitals are secondary-level health care facilities that serve as referral centers for primary health care institutions within a smaller administrative unit known as a block or taluk. They provide services like inpatient care, surgery, diagnostics, and specialized medical treatment, making them a higher level of care compared to Sub-Centres.

questions.text: You were given the charge of health services in a nearby school in a rural area. To whom should you provide the report/get information on school health services?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

When in charge of health services at a nearby school in a rural area, you should provide reports and get information on school health services from the Primary Health Centre (PHC).

Explanation of incorrect options

SC (Sub-Centre) (Option B): While Sub-Centres are the first point of contact between the primary health care system and the community, they primarily focus on providing health services at the community level and may not have specific programs or resources dedicated to school health services.

District hospital (Option C): District hospitals are secondary-level health care facilities that typically serve as referral centres for primary health care facilities. They are responsible for providing more specialized medical services and may not have direct involvement in school health services.

Sub-divisional health centre (Option D): Sub-divisional health centres are higher-level health care facilities than PHCs and typically serve larger geographic areas. Similar to district hospitals, they may not have direct involvement in school health services as their focus is on providing comprehensive health care services to the population within their jurisdiction.
